awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Seasonal climate change over the last two millennia from archaeological sources in the subtropical eastern North Atlantic region
awd_abstract_narration:
How has the seasonal range in sea surface temperature (SST) changed over the last two millennia along subtropical coasts that are inherently sensitive to human and climate impacts? Seasonally-resolved records of preindustrial climate in subtropical coastal settings are few but critical to understanding impacts on humans and ecosystems. The goal of this research is to reconstruct summer and winter SST during four warm vs. cold climate intervals from the last two millennia. This will be achieved using paleoclimate proxies (indirect measures of SST) preserved in shells from archaeological deposits accumulated by aboriginal people in the Canary Islands. Outcomes will advance knowledge of human-climate interactions, such as the long-term effects of climate variability on prehistoric human subsistence patterns and behavior in ecologically sensitive habitats. This project will train students from high school to PhD level, targeting undergraduate students from low-income households, first-generation college students, and members of under-represented ethnic groups, using established programs including McNair Scholars, Women in Science and Engineering, and Upward Bound Programs. Through the UNC Baccalaureate Education in Science & Teaching program, future high-school earth science teachers will perform research that will generate laboratory curricula for K-12 science courses. This project fosters international and multidisciplinary collaboration among scientists from the US and Spain. Results will be disseminated to both specialists and the general public in both English and Spanish, which will engage a diverse audience in the US and elsewhere. 
 
Using oxygen isotope (delta18O) time-series of radiocarbon-dated archaeological Patella candei (Mollusca: Gastropoda) shells from the Canary Islands, several critical abrupt multi-centennial warming and cooling transitions (Roman Warm Period, Vandal Minimum or Dark Ages Cool Period, Medieval Climate Anomaly, and Little Ice Age) will be examined and compared to the late 20th century. The main goals are to: (1) calibrate and validate oxygen isotope sclerochronology (shell growth patterns) of living specimens of P. candei with instrument records as credible repositories of seasonal SST; and (2) reconstruct SST profiles from radiocarbon-dated archaeological shells during important abrupt climate intervals over the last two millennia relevant to our rapidly warming world. Results from this investigation will be then used to explore temporal variations of the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), which is a key feature of atmospheric variability in the North Atlantic and mainly operates during the winter. The geographic location offers a unique opportunity to examine the NAO phase and its shifts in the subtropical fronts during preindustrial warming and cooling climate episodes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to generate unprecedented records of sea surface temperature (SST) at monthly resolution from the subtropical eastern North Atlantic Ocean during the last two millennia. Specifically, abrupt multi-centennial warming and cooling transitions between the Roman Warm Period (RWP: BC 250?AD 400), Vandal Minimum or Dark Ages Cold Period (VM: 550?800 AD), Medieval Climate Anomaly (MCA: 1000?1300 AD), and Little Ice Age (LIA: 1400?1800 AD) were examined using oxygen isotope (δ18O) time-series from archaeological shells of the European limpet, Patella candei, from the Canary Islands (latitude: 27-29?N). To accomplish this goal, we first calibrated the oxygen isotope ratios in shells of live-collected specimens to serve as a seasonal SST proxy. The successful calibration allowed us to reconstruct subtropical seasonal SST over the last two millennia, including the RWP, VM, MCA, and LIA transitions, using time-series oxygen isotope data from 14C-dated archaeological limpet shells.

Intellectual Merit and Key Outcomes

Based on our findings, we conclude that several gastropod species of the rocky intertidal zone in the Canary Islands are credible and reliable seasonal paleothermometers that can be used to reconstruct seasonal variations in SST over the last two millennia.

When working with archaeological shells, it is imperative to radiocarbon date each shell to establish a reliable chronology because we have shown how shells retrieved from the same stratigraphic horizon can exhibit up to multi-millennial age mixing beyond analytical error.

We also demonstrated that the rapid and more affordable carbonate-target radiocarbon dating method is effective for dating the shells of mollusc species from the Canary Islands, which is a great methodological advantage as this method is inexpensive compared to traditional graphite-target dating.

Archaeological shells that have been dated to the MCA age interval suggest that the study region (NW Africa) was up to 2?C colder than expected. Tentative interpretations of these data include that during the MCA, accelerated upwelling in NW Africa may have caused a rapid cooling episode, in contrast to model projections.

Our findings were published in four peer-reviewed papers. Data from this project have been presented in a total of six oral and poster communications at various scientific conferences.

Broader Impacts

The North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) is the main mechanism of atmospheric variability in the North Atlantic and mainly operates during the winter. A positive NAO is followed by warmer SST anomalies in the western subtropical North Atlantic, cooler SST anomalies in the subpolar gyre, and cooler SST anomalies off the coast of NW Africa (by the Canary Islands). A negative NAO results in an opposite trend. NAO shifts have been linked to extensive warming over the past few decades. Uncertainties continue about NAO dynamics over the past few millennia because seasonal proxies that capture winter SST are rare. This research generated winter (and summer) SSTs useful to paleoclimatologists and climatologists interested in assessing temporal variations in NAO shifts beyond instrument records. The geographic location offers a unique opportunity to examine the NAO phase and its shifts in the subtropical fronts during preindustrial warming and cooling climate episodes, data so far unavailable for the scientific community and society. This research generated data to test if preindustrial NAO variability is comparable to post-industrial times and to explore how humans may have interfered with NAO dynamics.

This NSF-funded project is the second lead by PI Yanes, a Hispanic early-career female at the University of Cincinnati. The execution of this project has been crucial for her professional development in North America, and for consolidating scientific collaborations with PI Surge. This project has allowed PI Yanes to recruit several undergraduate and graduate students. Thus, PI Yanes has greatly increased her skills as a mentor at higher-education levels in North America.

This project has provided research and mentoring opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and an early career, postdoctoral researcher. These opportunities include engaging young women in scientific research. PIs Surge and Yanes recruited undergraduate students from underrepresented groups to participate in this research. The students presented their findings at scientific conferences, allowing them to hone their scientific communication skills and engage with other scientists in our field.
